Question.Subject: What is the update on the US adaptation of Christian and Oliver from Verbotene Liebe?
Question.Content: Verbotene Liebe is a German soap. To be more specific there's a plan to make a US version of the storyline of Christian and Oliver ("Chrolli"). Last news about it was in early 2010. What's the update for it?
Question.ChosenAnswer: Never heard of it..it would be nice to have another soap though..maybe if you google it they might have some info...=)

Question.Subject: Is there anyway to find the first episode of Verbotene Liebe?
Question.Content: I know it started in 1995, and I would love to be able to see the first episodes. Anyone know how?

Question.Subject: Is there a difference in pronouncing liebe and leben in German?
Question.Content: What do these words mean in German and how do you pronounce them? Thanks!
Question.ChosenAnswer: Yes there is. Liebe is the verb 'to love' and leben is the verb 'to live'. Liebe is pronounced 'lee-beh' and leben is pronounced leh-ben''

Question.Subject: How do you pronounce liebe and lebe in German?
Question.Content: I'm having a hard time distinguishing these two words, are they pronounced the same way?
Question.ChosenAnswer:
Liebe - lee-buh lieben [the verb] LEEbun Lebe - lay- buh leben [the verb] LAYbun
if you get yourself a good German dictionary [assuming you're learning German] it will include advice on pronunciation

Question.Content: please help,where can i watch the full serie Verbotene Liebe? i want to watch full episode but not in youtube,dailymotion and hulu because they never work in my country.
Question.ChosenAnswer:

Was that it?

Question.Subject: How do you say "Ich liebe dich so sehr" in short form, or kurzform?
Question.Content: I know in English it means "I love you" or something thereabouts but I need to know the German version. Thanks in advance!
Question.ChosenAnswer: There's no short form of "Ich liebe dich so sehr" because it means "I love you so much". "Ich liebe dich" means "I love you". It's really NOT the same to say "I love you so much" or to say "I love you" so plain and simple.

Question.Subject: Is there any meet and greets for fans of VERBOTENE LIEBE in the USA to meet Thore and Jo?
Question.Content: If not is there a way to get their autographs?
Question.ChosenAnswer: I can't imagine so, considering it doesn't even air in this country! They ought to have fan pages, track one down for an address, you can send them a pic for them to autograph that they can mail you back.

Question.Subject: What does liebe dich mean EXACTLY in German?
Question.Content: i've translated it on bing translator to "love you" but i've heard that it has a different meaning from "ich liebe dich" which is "i love you"....which really doesn't make much sense to me....anyone here to clarify?
Question.ChosenAnswer: it sounds like "love you" to me. if, for some reason, in some part of Germany, there's a slang subliminal message that makes it differ from its dictionary translation, or from "i love you," then it's not evident in the words themselves.

Question.Subject: Where can i find the TV show Verbotene Liebe -christian and oliver) on DVD? Is it even on DVD?
Question.Content: I am looking for the German TV show Verbotene Liebe (Forbidden love- christian and oliver) on DVD but i am having trouble finding anything. If anyone can help, even if its just to know that it isnt available, i would greatly appreciate it.
Question.ChosenAnswer: I love that show, they are the cutest couple. They have a website chrolli.de and a lot of videos on youtube, but no DVDs.

Question.Subject: How would you pronounce Ich Liebe Dich in German?
Question.Content: i am trying to pick up on some german and ich liebe dich means I love you. i got that memorized but how do you pronounce it? Is it eek laba deek or itch laba ditch? or is it something else? Does the CH in german make a K sound or a regular CHA noise? Please help me...
Question.ChosenAnswer:
No. There is one simple rule for German: most words are exactly pronounced as they are spelled. There are two versions of the "ch"-phoneme in German, one is voiced, the other one voiceless. The voiced one is pronounced like the ch in Loch Ness, the voiceless one is pronounced with less pressure. Imagine you try to hiss like a panther/ cat - that sound comes close to it. But the ch is never ever pronounced as "k" - only in southern dialects.
The e behind the i in "liebe" signifies that it is a long vowel like in the english "geek", whereas the i in "ich" and "dich" is a short vowel like in the english "hit".
So it's like Ich liiiiiiiiiiiiebe dich.
